reviewText: I must preface by saying that I like Kung Fu movies -- and I've seen my share of them. The Man with the Iron Fists has the body of a new style Chinese Martial Arts film like House of the Flying Daggers, the brains of Enter the Dragon, and the soul of Machete -- although it's not nearly as much fun as Robert Rodriquez's similar riff on the Mexican Gangster film. Fists isn't really a Chinese film at all, although plenty of the talent is from the Middle Kingdom, but instead is a re-envisioned fantasy of the Kung Fu genre through the eyes of Wu-Tang mastermind and rapper RZA. He wrote, directed, and starred.There's a lot to like in this film (as a Kung Fu fan). The characters are pretty memorable in a comic book, kung fu, video game kind of way. They each have their own weapons, powers, and gimmicks. A few of them are even well acted (or over acted) like Russell Crowe's entertaining performance as Jack Knife or Lucy Liu as Black Widow. Many have bad hair.RZA and his titular character forms the weakest link. He's just flat. His voice over is hard to understand and the rapper voice narrating Kung Fu feels totally out of place. But his music's good. And despite some nearly incoherent editing and minimal storytelling, the overall style is pretty decent.The villains are pretty darn cheesy, particularly the heavy metal fright wig hair styles of the Lion Clan, but whatever, it's a campy almost spoof of the Kung Fu genre. It's gory as hell too, but despite numerous brothel scenes, strangely chaste (no nudity at all). Hmmm, there's that weird violence is better than sex thing. What gives? A big chunk of backstory on RZA's character shoved into the middle of the film is a total snooze-a-rama, but other than  that, the action scenes are exciting and the brothel scenes funny, so if you like the genre, go for it. Just remember, it's just no Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and not even up to the standards of Kung Fu Hustle.Andy Gavin, author of The Darkening Dream and Untimed

reviewText: I love kung fu flicks, and grew up on those great Shaw Brothers films of the 1970's. I had heard that "The Man with the Iron Fists" was RZA's homage to those classic films, so I was pretty excited to give this view. Toss in "Hostel"'s Eli Roth and Quentin Tarantino...and this seems like a can't miss film.If you dig deep enough into through the rubbish, there is actually a decent story buried in here. A rogue clan wants to steal a shipment of the emperor's gold, and a small town gets caught in the middle. The town's blacksmith just wants to save enough money so that he, and the prostitute he's in love with can leave and start a new life together. From that basic story this huge mess comes spilling out, and nothing is coherant or enjoyable.You have a wonderful supporting cast with Ricky Yune, Lucy Liu and Russell Crowe all chewing scenery when given half a chance, but ultimately wasted in one pointless scene after another. Even if their characters were jammed into a brainless action film, it would be forgivable if the action were any good. It's not. There is plenty of bloody kicks and punches thrown, some wire fighting, some weapons tossed in, some cgi with WWE wrestler Dave Bautista occasionally turning into brass....all poorly, poorly filmed.This whole mess can be blamed on one guy,...RZA. Apparently he is a rapper, and occasional actor? I remember seeing his name on the "Kill Bill" soundtrack, but I can't say I'm familiar with him. He's all over this movie; he stars as the blacksmith, he's listed as the writer and is also the director. He's obviously very well connected, and was able to secure financing to put this thing into motion, but you really wish someone...anyone...would have stepped in here and put a stop to this mess before it got too far.Unenjoyable in an even "so-bad-it's-good" way, just a boring, kinetic mess, that you will kick yourself for wasting 90 minutes on.
summary: Amateur Film with a Professional Gloss

When I saw who handled it I thought "Aww S***!  Here we go.".  It's the RZA's Homage to the classic Kung Fu flicks He loves. RZA is the skilled village black smith with story narration.  Russel Crowe as Mr. Knife was quite amusing.  His weapons were neat.  Lucy Lui owns/owns a brothel, but her true identity & intentions is reveiled towards the end.  Former wrestling star David Bautista as Brass Body.  Need I say more?  Rick Yune as X-Blade, a walking swiss army knife, so to speak.  Plus a few more.The action was incredible.  At times, over the top with its numerous graphic scenes. What little kung fu that was displayed, was stunted due to the editing.Fast editing cuts work, if done right.  At times, it made the movie look like a complete mess.Then there's the RZA.  If he plans to star in a movie he directs, I would hope he'd spend extra time on his choreography in the future.  His fighting, or lack there of, was a kiddy pool filled with misery.  To make it worse, they tried to hide his handicap with special effects.I don't how well it would've done without Tarantino's name slapped on it, but all and all I did enjoy the movie.  It's worth a watch.  RZA pays his respects to Kung Fu flicks in his own vision.  I have no issues adding it to my collection. reviewText: RZA (born Robert Fitzgerald Diggs,  aka Prince Rakeem, Bobby Digital, Bobby Steels , The Abbott, Ruler Zig-Zag-Zig Allah, The Rzarector) is a Hip hop MC and influential producer best known for his work with Wu-Tang Clan.  Here he expands his influence by conceiving, writing, composing the musical score, directing and starring in this very strange movierama ,THE MAN WITH THE IRON FISTS.Madame Blossom summarizes the plot by saying `Power belongs to no one, until it is seized through sex or violence.'  One critic was able to give the pan for the story as follows: `In Jungle Village, the leader of the Lion's clan Gold Lion is summoned by the Governor (Terence Yin) and assigned to protect his gold that will be transported through the village. However he is betrayed and murdered by the greedy Silver Lion (lawyer/actor Byron Mann) and Bronze Lion (Cung Le). Gold Lion's favorite son Zen Yi, a.k.a. The X-Blade (Korean American famous fashion model Rick Yune), seeks revenge and heads to Jungle Village, but he is defeated by Brass Body (Dave Bautista) and rescued by the local Blacksmith Thaddeus (RZA). Meanwhile the Gemini Female (Grace Huang) and the Gemini Male (Andrew Lin) protect the Governor's gold, but they are vanquished by the army of Silver and Bronze Lion. The Blacksmith is abducted by the Lions and has his arms severed by Brass Body. However he is saved by the British Jack Knife (Russell Crowe), who is the emissary of the Emperor, and he manufactures iron arms for Thaddeus. Meanwhile the Governor sends the Jackal army to fight against the Lions and they hide the gold in the brothel of Madam Blossom (Lucy Liu). However, Madam Blossom and his girls form an army of black widows and together with Jack, Zen Yi and The Blacksmith, they fight against the Lions.Great costumes, extraordinary hair styles for men, pretty sets, flying action and blood blood blood are the main attractions here.  The story is supposedly set in feudal China but much of the dialogue and situations are very much of this decade. Filmed in Hong Kong and the US the characters are basically an Asian mix of what appears to be a cluster of American actors. One is left wondering how such people as Russell Crowe, Pam Grier (she plays RZA's mother) and Lucy Liu (and what did the publicized Quentin Tarantino do in this picture?) connected to this extended Oriental rap session. But in the end, if silly dialogue and absurd fights and lack of plot make for a colorful evening's escapist entertainment, then here it is. reviewText: RZA waited a long time to tell this story, this brainchild of his, inspired by untold hours of viewing kung-fu flicks during his formative years. The Shaw Brothers as baby sitters? Sure, why not. RZA grew up sort of a historian on kung fu pictures, this guy from Brooklyn who can go toe to toe, trivia for trivia, with Hong Kong action cinema experts like Bey Logan. And how does RZA's THE MAN WITH THE IRON FISTS stack up against classics like THE 36TH CHAMBER OF SHAOLIN, MAD MONKEY KUNG FU, and THE FIVE DEADLY VENOMS?Okay, THE MAN WITH THE IRON FISTS isn't the best martial arts film released stateside this year (That would be Iko Uwais's THE RAID: REDEMPTION). Whereas THE RAID: REDEMPTION grounded itself in vicious but realistic combat sequences, RZA's pet project is more steeped in the bizarre and the fanciful. A mythical element creeps in. In RZA's personal vision of wuxia, a fighter's flesh can transmutate into metal. A laborer, by dint of will power, can animate his prostheses. It's a fun show.In the 19th century, the freed slave Thaddeus Henry Smith (RZA) made his way to feudal China, and in the tiny Jungle Village has made a home. Thaddeus is a gifted blacksmith, a peaceful, quiet man. Except that the rough characters in Jungle Village frequently contract his metal-shaping services. And so the blacksmith reluctantly perverts the lessons he'd learned, and he forges jagged weapons of mayhem. Thaddeus's only haven lies in the arms of Lady Silk (Jamie Chung), a courtesan in the local brothel. He dreams of earning enough gold to buy out Lady Silk's contract from the brothel's madame (Lucy Liu). Then they'd go away together. So he keeps on making killing weapons. He turns a blind eye to his conscience.RZA's blacksmith is only one character in a plot that revolves around the Governor's gold shipment, and how all manner of hooligans go all out to obtain it. The central villain is the duplicitous Silver Lion (Byron Mann) of the Lion clan, him what just ruthlessly betrayed his leader, Gold Lion. Fast approaching is Zen Yi (Rick Yune), revenge-inclined son of Gold Lion and wearer of a suit of nasty blades. Today Silver Lion and his minions ride roughshod over Jungle Village. And is it a coincidence that Jungle Village is one of the stops in the gold shipment's itinerary? Does a bear crap in the woods? Is RZA fond of letters in caps?I admire RZA's efforts. Dude's a quadruple threat: he wrote, scored, directed, and acted in this movie. Those into martial arts movies may be aware of RZA's rep as a hardcore addict of kung fu cinema. RZA's been known to drop an audio commentary or two for past DVD releases (like THE 36TH CHAMBER OF SHAOLIN). Don't be surprised when RZA manages to rep the Shaolin Temple in a flashback sequence. Me, I enjoyed THE MAN WITH THE IRON FISTS. I wish that RZA hadn't been so understated in his performance. As the prohibitive protagonist, the sleepy-eyed RZA needed to generate more energy, more life. Thankfully, Russell Crowe picks up the slack, provides the swagger and the big personality as the enigmatic (and amusingly lecherous) Englishman, Jack (or "Mr. Knife"). Jack Knife is shady, his motivations murky. All we know is that he loves women and that he always brings a gun to a knife fight. You're kept guessing until the third act just which side he'll fall on. THE MAN WITH THE IRON FISTS is packed with amped-up wire-fu theatrics. The violence is brutal but so exaggerated it achieves an almost cartoonish vibe. Set your eyeballs on alert for cameos by Pam Grier and Hong Kong legend Gordon Liu. MMA fighter Cung Le has a supporting bit as Bronze Lion. As a bonus for the theater goer, THE MAN WITH THE IRON FISTS is presented by an onscreen Quentin Tarantino, after which he introduces a trailer for his upcoming DJANGO UNCHAINED.

reviewText: Rza bit off more than he could chew.  This movie shouldn't have been written AND directed AND scored AND starring Rza.  However, the movie was still loads of fun and Rza has definitely proven that he has great cinematic vision.  Expect many filmmaking imperfections, but enjoy the fun ride.Thaddeus (director Rza) is a gifted blacksmith whose talents are contracted by local warring clans.  He is pure of heart and wants nothing more than to purchase the freedom of his courtesan wife Lady Silk (Jamie Chung) from the brothel madame Blossom (Lucy Liu basically reprising her Kill Bill role).Thaddeus becomes mixed up in a plot to steal a large shipment of gold.  The main villain is Silver Lion (Byron Mann), who betrays the Lion clan leader with the help of Bronze Lion (Cung Le; Dragon Eyes).  Zen Yi (Rick Yune; Ninja Assassin), the son of the murdered clan leader, sets out to stop Silver Lion with his armor of retractable blades.  Also in the mix is Jack Knife (Russel Crowe), the most interesting and charismatice character (outside of combat) with an interesting taste for bachelor party shenanigans (i.e., Asian call girls, liquor and opium).The fighting in the movie was a mixed bag that will largely disappoint martial arts movie fans.  As the oddly bewigged lion clansman, Cung Le was sadly under-utilized.  He never gets to looks good or show off.  Not even in his finale fight against Lucy Liu.  The choreography presents a mix of very cool and very silly kung fu combat maneuvers.  Sadly, by and large the action is filmed way too close-up.  For me, the combat highlights should all be credited to Bautista's Brass Body.  He seemed to have the coolest scenes, obviously the coolest F/X because of his ability, and some of the most fun choreography that was filmed so that we could actually see it.Despite my complaints about much of the action, the kung fu theater feel was maintained undeniably well.  Rza captured that tone perfectly.  There was also a festive display of spewy-fun gore.The dialogue is dreadfully dry (except for Crowe's delivery).  Rza, God bless him for trying, can't act or effectively narrate.  His character was not only understated, but lacked the lines to justify his purpose.  It seems that Rza was going for a mood-driven film with stylized combat like Bunraku or The Warrior's Way.  I could see his goal, but his meant-to-be-poetic blacksmith character was clearly the weak link in synthesizing this quasi-arthouse-ful conceptual grace.  Rza tries to use a Shaolin Temple training flashback to corroborate Thaddeus' focus and combat ability.  Still, I found him to have zero combat credibility when facing Iron Body--a character who actually earned my respect on screen.The score (also by Rza) was cool during the first scene (a fight scene).  But I noticed less effective use of music later in the movie.  I'm not hating, it was a neat score.  But this was disappointing as I expected to have some awesomely rap-scored fight scenes, but some of them had combat volume drowning out the music, rendering it ineffective even at times that louder music would be appropriate.Director Rza--of the Wu Tang Clan--was always a devout fan of Hong Kong cinema's kung fu theater.  While his direction is clearly fledgling and his scoring ability nothing to his own rapping talent, his passion for classic kung fu movies manifested the greatest strength of this film: the kung fu theater "feel" of it all.  His excellent theatrical homage includes some classic kung fu movie components such as the iron body (brass body in the movie) focus style, techniques that are named after characters (e.g., the Gemini stance), the betrayal of one's master and the revenge that follows, the house of mirrors fight (which was unfortunately brief), traps and poison darts, fighters exploding from the ground in ambush and semi-flying combat maneuvers.  Perhaps the most fun was when all of the brothel whores turn out to be ninja-savvy combat-chic assassins.  Rza also covered the bases of kung fu weaponry, including bladed fans, bladed sleeve extensions, chain-fighting, various blades and good-old kung fu.This movie shouldn't have been written AND directed AND scored AND starring Rza.  However, the movie was still loads of fun and Rza has definitely proven that he has great cinematic vision.  I'd like to see him collaborate with more experienced film makers before attempting another solo venture like this.  But I am so glad that I got to see it anyway, imperfections and all.  This was a good debut considering his complete lack of experience since yet more experienced hands have failed to produce such entertainment time and time again.
summary: Rza has definitely proven that he has great cinematic vision. Expect many filmmaking imperfections, but enjoy the VERY fun ride.

reviewText: Note: May contain spoilers. Proceed with caution.In my opinion The Man With The Iron Fists is kind of a mixed bag. It's easy to fall in love with because it's obviously supposed to be over-the-top and cheesy, but at the same time nothing really feels memorable. To be honest I don't think I've actually seen a kung-fu movie so this is probably my first, but upon doing some research apparently what we see in The Man With The Iron Fists is pretty standard as far as martial arts films go.The story is a little difficult to explain due to the fact that it lacks any sense of direction. Basically we start off with the leader of the Lion clan, Gold Lion, getting assassinated. This leaves his two subordinates, Silver Lion (Byron Mann) and Bronze Lion (Cung Le), to take his place as leaders of the clan. Gold Lion was a leader who believed in peace while Silver Lion has a lust for war. In an effort to eliminate all traces of Gold Lion, he sends assassins to eliminate Gold Lion's only son, Zen-Yi aka The X-Blade (Rick Yune).After word got out that Gold Lion was assassinated, a mysterious man by the name of Jack Knife (Russell Crowe) arrives at Jungle Village. The viewer doesn't learn who he is or why he's there until the final 30 minutes or so. Until then he's staying at The Pink Blossom, a brothel run by Madam Blossom (Lucy Liu). Jack is probably one of my favorite characters because of his personality. He gives off this very calm, cool, collective vibe that Crowe does a wonderful job of pulling off. He's here for business and he doesn't have time to waste.My main reason for seeing this was RZA. Up until now he's appeared in some small roles here and there, but The Man With The Iron Fist is the first time he's getting the chance to play a major character. RZA plays an unnamed blacksmith who makes weapons for the rival clans. He's not on any specific side, he's just trying to save up enough money so he can leave Jungle Village with Lady Silk (Jamie Chung), his girlfriend and a prostitute at the Pink Blossom. I think the goal was to make this blacksmith the main character, but any effort to pull that off was eliminated when he's absent for majority of the first half.I think that's where I kind of got turned off. I enjoy films that follow a specific character/set of characters throughout the entire film. The Man With The Iron Fists is one of those films that jumps back and forth between multiple people. You have Silver Lion, Jack Knife, Madam Blossom, Brass Body (Dave Batista), and the blacksmith. Because there's so many key characters it's hard to form any sort of connection with any of them. That's not to say that they're all empty shells. On the contrary, I already mentioned my love for Jack, but Madam Blossom proves to be a pretty badass character and Brass Body (cheesy name aside) is interesting as well. The thing is that they only get brief spurts of screen time here and there which makes it hard to really care.My biggest issues, however, were the special effects and the predictability of the story. There's a scene within the first five minutes where a man is being attacked by a pack of wolves against what appears to be a barn door. It's obvious that these "wolves" are as fake as they come. In fact, these effects are so bad that when it cuts to this scene the color scheme changes from dark and solid to light and washed out. Then the fake blood used throughout the movie is just awful. There's been movies where the fake blood looks like fake blood, but this didn't even resemble blood at all. Whenever there was a spurt of blood erupting from a mouth, stab wound, etc. it looked like cherry soda. Part of me feels that this was intentional just to add to the cheesiness, but either way it just didn't do it for me.Then there was the story. Don't get me wrong, there were some things that I wasn't expecting, but majority of the time I said "This is probably going to happen." and sure enough it did. For example, there was a scene where the Lions stayed at The Pink Blossom and the women were ordered to "entertain" them. Right away I said "Lady Silk is going to get Brass Body". You wanna know what happened? Brass Body came into her room and wound up beating her to a pulp. I mean I understand that this is normal to include things like this because we've seen it done so many times in the past, but don't you think it's time that someone breaks the cycle?What really drives this film though is the performances from the cast members. It's clear that RZA is still a developing actor so don't expect some breathtaking performance, but considering that this is his first major role he did a solid job. Russell Crowe gave a great performance as Jack which more than makes up for his lackluster effort in Broken City. Rick Yune and Lucy Lui gave great performances as well, as did David Bautista, Byron Mann, and Jamie Chung. A lot of great performances from a pretty well-rounded cast.Overall Score: 6/10 - To be totally honest I expected more from The Man With The Iron Fists. From start to finish it felt really cluttered and directionless and the ending felt sudden and underwhelming. If you're a fan of kung-fu movies and you know what to expect then it would be very easy for me to recommend this to you. For everyone else I would advise you to go in with an open mind. While I personally can't say that I'll ever watch this again, I don't regret taking the time to experience it because when it's all said and done it was a nice ride.

reviewText: One man's opinion - Let me start by saying I watch movies... a LOT of movies.  On a given week I can easily view 15-20 movies - being permanently disabled has given me a lot of time on my hands.  Secondly, I LOVE BAD MOVIES... not all bad movies, but generally speaking the cheesier the better.  I love it when a bad movie crosses that invisible line between simply terrible to a new paradigm - what I like to call "So bad, it's good".  Need an example, "Battle Beyond the Stars" or as I like to call it John Boy in Space!!!  It's terrible, it's wonderfully, joyfully, nay, tearfully terrible.  Watch virtually ANY Christopher Lee horror film from the 60s or 70s.  You probably get the picture so I'll move on.  I bought this supposedly "Tarantino" film expecting bad - I wasn't disappointed (in that).It really didn't take very long to realize the only thing Quentin Tarantino had to do with this film was to make money off his name.  The filming of this movie had nothing of his quirkiness or well thought out scenes, none of his witty script-craft, and none of his skill in bringing a film to the silver screen.  What does appear on screen is a movie, poorly shot, poorly acted, poorly scripted, poorly organized, poorly scored.  The "short of it" in Texas parlance can be summed up thus - a hot mess, bless their hearts.How could this huge mistake have happened you might ask yourself (I sure did).  When a film goes this far off the ranch you have to start with the basics - who wrote the film - they are ultimately responsible for what's presented.  The film was written by Robert Diggs (East Coast Rapper and Wu-Tang Clan leader) and Eli Roth (of 'Hostel' and 'Hostel:Part 2' fame (ya, I missed those two too)).  The film was directed by Diggs... and stars Diggs as well (or as he self-styled RZA - a moniker which in this movie's case should stand for Razzle (Dazzle) since the film has so little substance and so much flash).  Mr. Razzle Dazzle also was responsible for the soundtrack (I know, big surprise there too).  RZA was clearly over his head in every way imaginable, the writing is sluggish and uninspired, the directing is amateurish, the soundtrack commits the ultimate sin - its so poorly married to what's happening on screen it pulls you out of the movie, and the acting was flat.  I can almost forgive RZA for his performance and ever-present hip-hop / hood-inspired language (what direction is 'Norf' anyway?  That's right, I'm 'axing' you), but the deplorable job done by both once A-List stars Russell Crowe and Lucy Liu leaves much to the imagination (and what you fill in for their apparent lack of enthusiasm wasn't good).  Crowe would seem to be going the way of Marlon Brando (all the girth and half the talent) and Liu's performance is a text book example of how she has gone from Lucy Liu to Lucy Who?  If I could give the film no stars I would.  It's not worth the cardboard it came wrapped in.  I hope Tarantino enjoyed the cash given to borrow his name and I sincerely hope he actually reads the next script before cashing the check - in this business we call show, reputation is everything and this was most certainly NOT a Tarantino film.  One or two of these and his fan base will take a walk (I hope your listening Mr. Tarantino, I'm still a fan... for now).  In summary - Hot Mess, RZA=Razzle Dazzle, Lucy Who? and DON'T BUY THIS FILM, DON'T EVEN RENT IT - just walk away... run if you're able.Bad movie, BAD movie - BAD MOVIE.  PS - Hollywood - DON'T GIVE RZA MONEY (unless you are looking for a tax write off, then it makes sense.)

reviewText: Man, where to begin?  Firstly, I am a life-long fan of martial arts films.  Everything from Kurosawa's 1943 (Judo vs Jujitsu) classic "Sanshiro Sugata", to the modern gore & brutality of 2011's "The Raid", and just about everything in between.  I fell in love with film fighting during the '80s, when I was allowed to stay up late to watch "Kung Fu Theater", featuring traditional Chinese fighting styles and costumes.  My discovery was probably not too long after the film's 1st time writer/director, RZA, began his own obsession with this particular brand of escapism.  When I first heard that RZA was writing and directing a kung fu movie, I could barely contain my excitement.  A while later, when I finally saw the first trailer for it, I could hardly contain my contempt.  It looked awful.  After unfavorable reviews started pouring in, I thought it best to cut my losses and avoid seeing it at all.  Many months passed until just last week, when it was available for checkout from my local library.  A trusted source's recent reserved recommendation sealed the deal.  I lowered my expectations and had a go.  I gotta say, there was some pretty cool stuff going on here.  Was it still disappointing?  Yes, but if I came away with anything, it's a sincere hope that RZA continues in this profession.  My man leapt right into the 35th Chamber of filmmaking, and while not graduating, I think he showed the monks he means business.In Jungle Village (kind of a late-1800s, Chinese version of Mos Eisley from "Star Wars"), powerful clans converge to steal a large portion of gold that will be escorted through town via the governor's order.  Knowing of the cutthroats that reside there, the governor has requested the extra security of the Lion clan.  The clan's leader, Gold Lion (Chen Kwan Tai, "Dragon Tiger Gate") agrees until his lieutenants, Silver (Byron Mann, "Belly of the Beast") & Bronze (Cung Le, "Dragon Eyes") betray and murder him.  Seems they want the gold for themselves.  Not taking the other clans too seriously, it seems the only real threat to their plan is Gold's son, Zen Yi, aka the X-Blade (Rick Yune, "Ninja Assassin"), and eventually Thaddeus (RZA, "Coffee & Cigarettes"), the town's blacksmith, whose business is booming with weapon requests for the impending rumble.  There are many other characters, including Russell Crowe  ("L.A. Confidential") as the Englishman, Jack Knife, and Lucy Liu ("Kill Bill") as the owner of the local brothel that EVERYONE frequents.I refuse to call out RZA for plagiarism because these types of films borrowed from one another quite liberally and I recognized most of his source material.  The majority of this picture was borrowed from "The Kid With The Golden Arm" (1979), "Flag of Iron" (aka "Spearman", 1980), and "Crippled Avengers" (1978): movies starring the group of 6 actors known as the Venom mob (from their most popular film together, "5 Deadly Venoms"), who worked for the Shaw Brothers studio in the mid-to-late '70s, specifically for the late director Chang Cheh ("One Armed Swordsman").  Elements are also borrowed from other Shaw flicks, like "Cave of the Silken Web" (1967) and "The 36th Chamber of Shaolin" (1978).The fight scenes?  It saddens me to report that, well, frankly, they suck.  The bullseye (or at least its periphery) of RZA's target audience is more-or-less me and had the kung fu been good I would've been absolutely enamored with this film.  Dreadful use of wires, editing, CGI gore, and slow motion totally sink the action.  RZA and co-writer Eli Roth ("Hostel") developed original weapons for the film and they're pretty sweet.  If only they had figured out a way to shoot the scenes where these items were utilized.  Rick Yune, Cung Le, and WWE/MMA fighter Dave Bautista (as Brass Body) are really the only ones that get to show off any good moves but they're still disappointing due to poor handling.The Universal DVD contains both R-rated and Unrated versions, coming in at 96 & 108 minutes, respectively.  The image is colorful and splendid with a nice 2.40:1 widescreen picture.  Spoken languages are available in English, Spanish, and French, with subtitles in English or French.  Special features include: deleted scenes, "A Look Inside...", "Path To The East", and "On The Set With RZA".  I really can't recommend this as a martial arts film but I can as a slice of kung fu nostalgia for old-school fans.  The casting was excellent and the acting, story, score, and direction were actually much better than I expected.  Sets & costumes were well done, too.  Really, everything but the action, which is kind of a big deal for this genre.2012

reviewText: Iron Fists' bloody and hyper real opening title sequence is perhaps the best evidence of what RZA had in mind when he started developing his love letter to East Asian cinema, and there's no denying the film's clever use of wirework and sublime imagery to sell that notion. The production's use of authentic Chinese locations also offers a sense of visual grandeur.Where Iron Fists falls apart is in its contrived mythology. While it's obvious that RZA and co-writer Eli Roth spent a lot of time developing this complex universe filled withwarring clans, mystic ideologies and thorough backstories, none of those ever become fully realized over the course of the movie, even with the Unrated Edition's extended runtime. Instead of a restrained, balanced narrative, the director spends more time cramming in as many tributes to past works as he can, without establishing his own unique style. As a result, Iron Fists becomes less of a modern spin on a classic genre and more of a muddy, bombastic tribute video.That's not to say the film isn't without SOME  entertainment value. Iron Fists' over-the-top fight sequences are among some of its strongest moments, and the choreography is, on the whole, impressive. Admittedly, RZA is probably the weakest link in terms of both fighting and acting. However, martial artists Rick Yune, Byron Mann and Cung Le add some credibility to the choreo, and Russell Crowe turns out a fun performance as the gunblade-slinger Jack Knife.It's just a shame none of these elements form any  kind of cohesive whole.

reviewText: As the first mainstream American kung fu movie to be produced in about ten years, I promised myself to see it. I wasn't sure what to make of its first-time director, but by and large I was excited for it. However, I ended up not getting to see the picture until recently, and by then, some trepidation had built up for me, based on the lukewarm reviews I had come across. I'm glad for them, because this would have been a pretty big letdown otherwise. "The Man with the Iron Fists" is an entertaining action flick and certainly not bad, but stylistic choices by the filmmakers hinder what could have been a very good adventure and dilute it to mere little more than a visually interesting time-killer.The story: an assortment of warriors, assassins, and various deadly individuals - all in pursuit of treasure - descend on a small town overseen by a unique blacksmith (director and rap star Robert "RZA" Diggs)...Director and leading man RZA is a hardcore fan of traditional kung fu flicks, and producer-in-spirit Quentin Tarantino is big on retro repackages. They have fine ideologies, but I'm fairly certain that the movie could have been made without being so ridiculously hokey. The cheesy opening titles, the recycled Shaw Bros. sound effects, the cartoon gore, and a good deal of the dialogue are constant reminders that the filmmakers didn't take their product very seriously, and I'm a bit resentful for it. Not only does this seem to act as a waiver for any technical shortcomings (see the unrated version, mainly), but all of this had already been done better a decade ago with Tarantino's ownKill Bill. Guys, it's *okay* to fill a movie full of cool things; you don't have to account or apologize for it with comedy.And there certainly is a good deal of cool things to be found here. Artistically, the movie is a success, with great sets and unique costumes. Many of the special weapons I had never seen before. The storyline is juicy, and it moves at a swift comic book pace that I find appealing. And the casting is, for the most part, full of winners. Rick Yune (Ninja Assassin) as a main hero, Lucy Liu as the deadly madam of a brothel, and ex-WWE star Dave Bautista as a monstrous enforcer - good. Byron Mann (Street Fighter) as the lead villain, Kwan Tai-Chen (The 5 Deadly Venoms) as his ill-fated father, and MMA champ Cung Le as the former's main henchman - very good. David Wu (Legend of the Black Scorpion) as a creepy assassin and the singular Gordon Liu as the teacher of RZA's character - fantastic. RZA himself gives a much better performance than expected. I have no idea what Kurt Russell is doing in this movie, but in the end, his performance as the horny gunslinger is endearing.Of course, the best action cast in the world is only as good as its action scenes, and disappointingly, I think these fights could have been better. They could have been a lot worse, of course, but considering the amount of talent involved and that they're wrangled by Corey Yuen - one of my favorite action coordinators - they definitely fall short of their potential. There isn't a single fight scene that I can point to as an example of a great cinematic brawl. Part of this is due to the style in which they're choreographed; I'm not a huge fan of wire-fu. Nevertheless, the wirework shows some ingenuity (e.g. the Gemini fight), and in the end, the biggest drawbacks of the brawls are that too few of them feature any amount of satisfying back & forth action and that too many of them feature an overabundance of slow motion and CGI enhancements. These are clearly supposed to be Hong Kong-styled fights, but come off more as Americanized Hong Kong knockoffs.With that said, there are several good (not great) fights, among them the showdown between RZA and Bautista's characters, which is better than it has any right to be in my opinion. I think that's the best way to approach this movie - with low expectations, so that you're pleasantly surprised at the highlights and not too disappointed by the shortcomings. For his junior outing as both an actor and a director, RZA does a good job, but I think he was held back by both the ambitiousness of this project and the influence of the folks who were supporting him (read: writer-producer Eli Roth). I'd be interested in watching the sequel that's set up during the credits, but that one will have a lot it needs to build on if it's going to be better than this.

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of the old time kung fu movies. When I saw the trailer for Man With The Iron Fists it looked like a movie tailor made for me. Boy was I wrong.I watched the first half of the movie before growing bored and wandering out of theater. During the many hours I spent watching the first half - or at least it seemed that long - I saw absolutely nothing to indicate that any actor or stunt-man appearing in the movie had ever had a martial arts lesson. Seriously, the fight choreography looked like what a bunch of school boys, with absolutely no martial arts background, might put together trying to copy what they saw in Kung fu Theater. Maybe there was some martial arts in the 2nd half of the movie, I didn't make it that far. I later learned that there were a couple real martial artists in this movie. Based on what I saw on the screen, I never would have figured that out.What Iron Fist did have, in abundance, was lots and lots of bright red fluid. I couldn't begin to tell you how many limbs were severed in the first 15 minutes. There was one scene where one "martial artist" rips the arms off another "martial artist" using something that was possibly some kind of tiger style. There was a guy in a suit full of switchblades that does a lot of jumping and spinning and severing of arteries. There's also Russell Crowe who seems to know even less about fighting than the uncoordinated "martial artists." But he has a pair of scissors with a pistol grip that he uses to disembowel his clumsy opponents.The sets and cinematography were first rate, impressive but not impressive enough to make up for the terrible writing, directing and fight choreography. The costumes looked like a lot of thought and a lot of money had gone into them. Iron Fist had a $20 million budget, and was shot in China where that kind of money will go pretty far. It's a shame that RZA didn't spring for a first rate choreographer. But it's also a shame that the movie wasn't better written and directed. The real shame of it is that all the ingredient to make a good kung fu movie were in place, the only thing missing was a recipe and someone who knew how to mix them.If you're a fan of simulated blood, simulated amputations and simulated disembowelments - and couldn't care less if anyone on the screen could actually kick their way out of a paper bag - this is the movie for you. If you want to see some actual martial artists with real skill and real choreography, get yourself some Shaw Brothers kung fu DVDs and skip watching this steaming pile.

reviewText: Having watched several of the Shaw Brothers classics during my day, I can definitely see where Rza got his inspiration for this movie. The only problem is, he created a bad Kung Fu fantasy instead of putting out a memorable film. As many people have already described this film in detail, I'm not going to go into the plot. But suffice to say, Rap music doesn't belong in a 19th century period piece. It just doesn't. Rza would have been better off getting the film properly scored instead of creating a Rap soundtrack for the background music. It was very distracting.Second, Rza choosing to have an African American character in the film, working as a blacksmith, might have worked. The only problem is, he chose to play the role himself. I have to agree with what others have already stated. Rza is not a very good actor in general. Add to that his street flare as he delivers his lines, and you have a mismatch character who doesn't really belong in the story. As a result, It was difficult to buy into his role. Had he picked a seasoned actor instead, it might have worked out. But as is, this film was likely a life long dream of his, so I guess he had to fit himself in somewhere. In retrospect, it was a mistake.I commend him, however, for tapping into the Asian American acting pool for his lead roles. Lucy Lui did well enough, as did Ricky Yune. Jamie Chung also appears in the film as Rza's love interest, but she doesn't really get enough screen time to leave her mark. It seemed like she was mainly there to give Rza's character a connection to the film. Russell Crowe also  appears  and his acting is always good. But in this case,  he seemed out of place. His character was odd and seemed to be written in just to have an excuse for more star power on the screen. At least, that's the way it seemed to me.The martial arts were OK, but they don't hold a flame to the HK classics from the 70's and 80's. My advice is, if you want a good Kung Fu flick, just go to the source. Either check out some Shaw Brother's films or look for some filmed  by Golden Harvest Pictures. They have real Kung Fu stories that work while showcasing excellent Kung Fu. Rza's  version is more of a Kung Fu parody that pays homage to the genre, but doesn't really hit the mark.In the end I gave the film 2 stars. Rza did manage to insert some of the  ideas you expect in a Kung Fu flick. He also enlisted the aide of  Asian American actors, so he gets another star for that. But overall, this is not a great film. It's just too far out of the norm to be a good Kung Fu flick. All you're left with while watching this film is a lingering hope that it might improve. But unfortunately, it never does. Definitely a one time rental at best.

reviewText: The Man with the Iron Fists(released Nov/12)stars,among others,RZA,the blacksmith Thaddeus,Rick Yune as Zen-Yi,X-Blade,Russell Crowe as Jack Knife,Lucy Liu as Madam Blossom,David Bautista as Brass Body,Jamie Chung as Lady Silk,Cung Le as Bronze Lion,and Byron Mann as Silver Lion.This film is a throwback to the 60s and 70s Hong Kong films that have inspired many producers,directors and actors over the years.Those films were originally for the most part fantasies,some serious others not.Some could even be considered Chinese westerns.They made big stars out of many of the actors in their home countries.What we in North America saw was oft times poor,faded prints with horrible dubbings into English.They became a joke and the plots,to us,were mostly forgettable.They have been lampooned consistently over the years since.This film plays it all very straight but uses the same style as those old Hong Kong pictures.Unfortunately the story is as lame as any of the poorest Hong Kong films and drags interminably to the end.The story finds the setting in China,in a time of feuding clans.The emperor has a shipment of gold traveling across the country and the head of the lion clan intends to protect it for him.However two of his underlings kill him and take over,and they scheme to steal the gold.Thrown into this mix is the son of the slain leader,X Blade,Jack Knife a mercenary British soldier who,with X Blade,converge on Jungle Town and meet up with a black,blacksmith,whose specialty is forging weapons of the finest calibre.Since the lion clan is no longer in the picture the governor sends the Gemini squad to protect the gold.They arrive in the town with it and hunker down in the hotel/brothel run by Madam Blossom.The lion clan kill the Gemini`s and commandeer the gold.They also sever the blacksmiths arms,who ends up forging iron fists onto his stumps.He teams with Jack Knife and X Blade to try and take down the lion clan.The clan makes a deal with the madam,who has the gold in storage beneath the brothel.She knows its a promise they will never keep so she strikes back first by killing almost all of its members the night before they are to leave.Arriving outside the city a platoon of well armed soldiers sent by the Emperor enters the town and are paused outside the brothel and ready to level it if the gold is not forthcoming.The three fight and defeat their enemies and Jack Knife,in the nick of time,appears to stop the soldiers from firing.The film ends as all three go their separate ways.In an epilogue X Blade`s wife is kidnapped by members of a bird clan and he must rescue her.He returns to the blacksmith for help.As in the old Hong Kong films the fights usually don`t take much time to break out and this film is no different.It also uses those,now,cheesy stunts and close ups of faces distorted in rage to propel things along,like the old Hong Kong-ers(the memories just come flooding back!).When the fights resume in earnest near the end of the film at the climax,they now use a more modern style to stage them,with quick camera movement,action freezing and the like.In between we have this long and drawn out plot as each character and group are introduced.We even get back stories on some of the characters.One such borefest is the backdrop to the blacksmith`s story.As if things weren`t going slowly enough,they had to insert that story to slow things almost to a halt.If this film had been sending the entire Hong Kong genre up,or was doing it in a visually stylistic interpretation ala Crouching Tiger,Hidden Dragon,this film may have stood some chance of being half decent.As it is,to actually have the nerve to play this thing ``straight``,is to commit filmic suicide.Sorry Mr.Diggs,this is bad.Technically speaking the film is in its w/s a/r of 2:40:1 and is clear and crisp.Extras include deleted scenes and some featurettes.This disc also contains the theatrical AND the extended versions.All in all a film that falls totally flat and into its Hong Kong rice bowl.If you,like I,were expecting a bit of imaginative tricks and style ala Crouching Tiger,Hidden Dragon,then think again.Just because it has Tarantino`s name attached,doesn`t mean it is on Tarantino`s level.

reviewText: Anyone remember watching Black Belt Theatre on Saturday afternoons?This movie gives off that same old school kung fu vibe as those classic 70's Shaw Brothers classics. reviewText: When a movie is "presented by" Quentin Tarantino, written by the RZA and Eli Roth and stars Russell Crowe and Lucy Liu you have a right to at least expect it to resemble a professionally made film. The new would-be Wuxia epic the Man With the Iron Fists is like an amateur production ,a bastardized cross between a Shaw Brothers martial arts adventure and a feature length movie trailer. Full of hype and missed potential, this is no better than any random cheaply made direct-to-DVD movie without big names. In this case so much talent, equals so much waste.First time director RZA is a well known fan of classic martial arts films, his rap group the Wu Tang Clan used a great deal of wuxia imagery in their music, starting with their name. If RZA does in fact love the genre, this is a bad representation of that, treating the wuxia genre as little more than a joke, one that`s not funny either. In a post Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon-era, the desire to apologize for martial arts movies would seem to no longer be a needed defense.Wuxia, the current cool in thing for westerners to call the martial arts genre, in Chinese it means heroic or chivalrias martial arts stories.  Wuxia pictures have been around nearly as long as movies themselves, but only recently have they ascended to there rightful place in Western film culture. The genre is now excepted, with critically studies that have allowed the once ghettoized genre a well deserved appreciated,These movies share much in common with the American western, easterns if you will, and like the western many of the best folk tales told in their culture have unfold on film within this noble genre. It is also worth noting that a lot of these movies are nearly as good as the classic American westerns, especially the HK Shaw Brothers titles of the 60's and 70's and directors  such as Cheng Cheh, King Hu and Li Chuai Ling are comparable to the likes of Sam Peckinpah, John Sturges or Anthony Mann, Now we add this movie to the association, one that is not only an embarrassment, but an insult, the Man With the Iron Fists takes the accomplished merits back several decades.The script is ludicrous, jumbled, disoriented and rambling. Eli Roth came on board to help RZA form and finish his screenplay, I can't imagine he did a lot of  the finished work, while not a tremendous writer. Roth's work usually is far more creditable than this.The dialogue in the Man With the Iron Fist is excruciating, spoken with corny sincerity. This no doubt is meant to be "homage" to the old English dubbed kung fu epics of the past, now does that not sound like a mistake. It just doesn't work when the lips match up with these unspeakable lines of discourse.Russell Crowe adds class and credibility, which are otherwise sorely lacking. Crowe has top billing, but plays a rather thankless supporting role, but offers an occasional distraction from the rest of the frivolities. Crowe also has never looked so out of shape, with his full beard and middle age spreading he's starting to resemble Orson Welles. Just why did Crowe do this film, it's mind-boggling to think of such a talented actor and huge movie star wasting his offerings on this.Lucy Liu is likeably enthusiastic, but the role is under developed and she's left floundering. Part of the reason for this is that the whole movie is terribly misogynistic, the woman are all whores and are either treacherous or just merrily in the way, one character is both. Liu's presence will also no doubt make viewers recall the far superior Kill Bill.The rest of the cast is a liability, "WWE superstar" Dave Bautista once again shows he has no acting skills what so ever. UFC champ Cung Le is still failing at his attempts to be a movie star. Rick Yune and Jamie Chung have to little screen time to make much impact as token Asian heroes. Pam Grier, Gordon Liu and Chen Kuan-tai show up in pointless cameos that just remind you of better movies you could be watching. As an actor RZA is better than he is a director, but not noticeably so. Playing the film's title character and narrator, like his direction, RZA speaks a lot, but says little.Is it too much to ask for the Man With the Iron Fists  to at the very least be a fun guilty pleasure, but no such luck. The movie lacks any sort of post Tarantino-style of self aware humor, or any intentional humor at all. The film is too brutally gory for it's own good , it is also unnecessarily profane, which does not keep with the genre's traditions, but seems designed to appeal to the hip-hop crowd. It is all so predicable, terribly derivative and worst of all boring. It is a long ninety-six minutes when a martial arts movie lacks even the credibility of a Kung Fu Panda flick.Cheaply made and very much looking it, I have to seriously wonder if RZA's intentions were not to make a bad movie. If so, he has succeeded beyond his wildest dreams. This is not like Tarantino and Rodriguez's Grindhouse, which had a lot of fun making bad movies better. The Man With the Iron Fists manages to make good movies appear bad.In theory this movie should have rocked, but it does anything but. RZA proves to be a lousy writer, a half assed actor and worst no filmmaker. RZA allegedly spent some seven years trying to get this made and the original run time is said to have been four hours long, I do have to ponder if it was any more coherent, but glad I don`t have to find out.  .RZA does fill the movie with an effective audible soundtrack, from hip-hop numbers to Cantonese pop tunes, not to mention a nicely rousing score. The movie looks good, it's visually striking with clever editing and good photography, but lousy action sequences in a dull and unpleasant turkey. The tagline is that this puts the f.u. in kung fu, that's not clever, that's just being honest.see my reviews at moviezonemagazine.com

reviewText: RZA loves Hong-Kong martial arts movies. Even if you don't know the origin of his group's name Wu-Tang Clan, you know that for sure after watching "The Man with the Iron Fists" RZA stars and directs. Together with such famous actors like Russell Crowe and Lucy Liu, RZA's feature debut includes such veteran Chinese actors as Kuan Tai Chen, Ka-Yan Leung and Chia Hui Liu (credited as Gordon Liu), the star of, yes, "The 36th Chamber of Shaolin."Unfortunately, loving something is one thing; making it actually is another. "The Man with the Iron Fists" just doesn't have a good story to tell, and a central character that hold our attention throughout the film's running time. Here RZA plays the titular reluctant hero, a skilled weapon-making blacksmith in the 19th century Chinese "Jungle Village," where warring clans fight over power, money and honor.But I'd rather not summarize the plot which is slow and pretty dull. To be fair, the martial arts sequences are interesting, being choreographed by Cory Yuen (choreographer of "The Transporter" and many others). The gorgeous production design, with the set made in China, is also impressive.This is RZA's homage to the 70s exploitation movies including Shaw Brothers kung-fu films. Like Tarantino's "Kill Bill," the film is made with love for the genre, but that is not enough to make a compelling action movie that stands on its own.
